data.title: Viewport doesn't scroll after expanding all
data.body:
### Description

After unfolding, the viewport should scroll to the cursor, instead it stays on the previous (to fold) scroll position.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Put the cursor in a line above the viewport first position.
2. Fold. _The cursor should stay in the same line or his parent if it was inside the block._
3. Unfold. _The cursor will appear stay in the correct position but the viewport didn't scroll._

**Expected behavior:** The viewport should scroll to the cursor position.

**Actual behavior:** The viewport stays on the position after _expanding_.
### Screenshot

![atom-viewpost-issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1685621/13543261/3b3db466-e248-11e5-8722-9013aee08cfc.gif)
### Versions

Atom: `1.42`. _Tested on v1.5.4 as well_.
OS: `OS X 10.11 Beta`.

data.title: As soon as I Run atom , I can't do anything but just debugging atom and thinking of ways to make atom more awesome ,  Bug Or By Design?
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)? 
  Yes , both
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)? 
  Latest Master and every other single version since birth of atom.
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)? 
  Yes
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)? 
  Yes
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? 
  Yes
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
  Yes
### Description

As soon as I Run atom , I can't do anything but just find atom bugs and start thinking of ways to make atom more awesome ,  Bug Or By Design? 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Run Atom
2. ????
3. Profit!

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]  
Start Coding  on my projects.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened] 
Start debugging for Atom.
### Versions : every single one of them.

data.title: Zooming text forces text out of viewable area
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Zooming the font size does not keep any portion of the original text on the screen.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Launch Atom
2. Open a file with at least a couple hundred lines of text
3. Press <kbd>Cmd+=</kbd> repeatedly

**Expected behavior:** Either the top-, bottom- or middle-most line of text to stay within the viewable area

**Actual behavior:** Zoom far enough and none of the top-, bottom- or middle-most lines stay within the viewable area
### Versions
- Atom: 1.7.0-dev-c782bdd
- Electron: 0.36.8
- Chrome: 47.0.2526.110
- Node: 5.1.1
- apm  1.7.1
- npm  2.13.3
- node 0.10.40
- python 2.7.10
- git 2.7.2

data.title: Serialize MarkerLayers only on quit
data.body:
Depends on https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/136.

Closes #10966.

After #10605 we have noticed some slowdowns during multi-cursor edits which we have tried to address in #10925 by switching from structured cloning to `JSON.stringify` when we had to serialize state. Even though that was faster, it led to several issues like stringifying cyclic structures and taking more and more time as the `History` grew over time.

With this PR we still continuously save the `AtomEnvironment`'s state, but we try to address the above concerns by: 
1. Incrementally converting history changes to a binary format. (https://github.com/atom/atom-patch/pull/7)
2. Serialize marker snapshots only before quitting. Although this won't maintain selection after hard crashes, the user history will always be preserved.

The result is the following: 

![screen shot 2016-03-04 at 17 43 44](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13533433/b67d40dc-e230-11e5-9789-7a1e993cba9a.png)
![screen shot 2016-03-04 at 17 44 03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13533434/b6b32d3c-e230-11e5-8252-90958f4de929.png)

(**Total:** `~ 40ms`, benchmarks performed by simultaneously writing 5 characters on 1500 lines)

Those `~ 34ms` will only be payed the first time new history entries need to be serialized, because we will reuse a cached binary representation of them whenever they need to be serialized again.

As a byproduct, and thanks to history's internals restructuring, undos/redos with many overlapping changes will get faster, as we compose and merge them without repeating some of the work for the intersecting regions.

It would be awesome to have some feedback on this, especially to understand how this feels to you performance-wise after a test-drive.

What's missing:
- [x] Bump text-buffer after merging the related PR.

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: Markdown code snippets: incorrect syntax highlighting
PHP syntax highlighting is broken when using "long comment type" within PHP-Tags
data.body:
### Description

Having a PHP code like below, does Atom let everything after the closing <?php */ ?> still interpret as "comment type" until the end of the file. This does not happen in other editors like UltraEdit, Brackets or Bbedit. Possible to get this changed? I am using mainly OSX.
### Steps to Reproduce

`<?php /* ?>
some non-php output here (JavaScript, HTML, whatever...)
<?php */ ?>
`

data.title: Move Pane::addItem 'pending' option to options object
data.body:
The API for adding pending pane items is pretty verbose; combined with ddb08d0c46ccf6408c5e7618fedd6cfc93bbad50, the argument list to `Pane::addItem` was getting pretty long, and it's easy to imagine it getting longer. This collapses things into an options object.

/cc @nathansobo re: the commit above; since the part of the API that changed was never publicly documented I assume it's fine to change for 1.6.

/cc @kuychaco the pending-ness :crown:

data.body:
### Prerequisites

[What actually happened]

Autocomplete for scss files doesnt seem to work when using mixins. 

Basically when you are inside a mixin such as @include breakpoint(...){ .... } 

Autocompletion doesnt work. Any ideas on how to fix this? 
### Versions

Atom 1.5.4

data.title: Suggestion: Reopen Window in Dev Mode
data.body: There's currently an _"Open in Dev Mode..."_ command under the _Developer_ submenu: I can't speak for other developers, but there've been numerous times when I've started working on something Atom-related, and I need to reopen the current project in dev mode. For instance, I'm working on a [language package](https://github.com/Alhadis/language-apl), so I need to see changes to pattern-matching expressions instantly... but stupid me keeps forgetting to open a project in dev-mode before I start working on it. Since I don't usually need to do that. ## What would be ace: A shortcut under _"Open in Dev Mode..."_ called _"Reopen window in dev mode"_ (greyed out if already in dev-mode) that does exactly what that 25-byte sequence implies. I understand this could be achieved with a package, but to be honest, this functionality feels too rudimentary to omit from Atom's core command-set.

data.title: Patch Environment On OSX And Allow A Different Environment Per Window
data.body:
- [X] ~~Create an `atom.project.getEnv` API~~
- [X] Fixup `PATH` on OS X when `TERM` is not set
- [X] Patch `process.env` on startup
- [x] Receive passed in environment variables on subsequent launches

Fixes #11037
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6956

data.title: Ensure atom.cmd --wait correctly waits in Windows cmd & powershell
data.body:
Existing solution caused Command Prompt to exit and sleep command is not built in to Windows.

New solution works by spawning powershell child process that passes it's PID to atom and then waits indefinitely. When atom terminates that process the parent process continues.

Tested in Command Prompt and Powershell in Windows 7 32-bit and Windows 10 64-bit.

data.title: Can't Cmd-V paste into file open dialog in OSX
data.body:
### Prerequisites

yes to all - pre-req's
### Description

Cannot paste a string into the file open dialog prompt
### Steps to Reproduce
- Open file dialog - Cmd o
- "Go to folder" - Cmd-shift g - opens a text input box
- backspace to clear default text, OK so far
- Paste (or try to) in path - Cmd v  - does nothing.

![screen shot 2016-03-03 at 5 29 42 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/499317/13515363/915f22a0-e165-11e5-8d98-f2c68980e66c.png)
At this point I wold expect my clipboard contents to appear in the file dialog prompt box. Instead, nothing happens.

However, I can paste in there using Rt-click - paste with the mouse.
### Versions

%> atom --version
1.5.3

data.title: Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/Users/davidstamen/Library/Application ...
Multiple instances of Atom, multiple versions in Finder right-click menu
data.body:
### Description

Atom has multiple instances open. And there's two versions of atom in the Open File With... Finder context menu.
### Steps to Reproduce

Open files in Atom. I use the Dock drawer, Finder context menu and `atom` command line tool to open things in Atom.

**Expected behavior:** One instance of Atom, multiple windows.

**Actual behavior:** 2+ instances of Atom, each with own Dock icon.
### Versions

1.5.3 and 1.5.4 (apparently, according to right-click menu)

data.title: Mac OS X > Git not found
data.body:
ERROR:
Multiple packages not finding git installation on Mac OS X. I have git installed. I updated it from git src and by using Homebrew. It works perfectly within Terminal. 

Atom seems to be looking for git and cannot find it. Is there some place within Atom that I can set the path to the git bin so that Atom and all of it's packages will find it?

My $PATH is already set to the correct path.
My simlinks are set to the correct path.
Besides Atom, all other applications are happy.

This is an ongoing issue with multiple users who do an update to git beyond the outdated version included in the Apple Dev Tools. 

I found this:
https://discuss.atom.io/t/unmet-git-dependency/14707/13

Suggestions:
- Better documentation and more detailed resolution instructions in error messages for this issue when it occurs in Atom. 
- Additionally, Atom could provide an input box in the global Settings to allow the user to provide a custom path to the git bin.

data.title: Atom freezes when switching workspaces in compiz (Linux)
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)? Yes, 1.6.0-beta6
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Atom starting freezes when switching workspaces in compiz until i reboot machine (restarting Xorg doesn't help).
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Work some time with some tasks (or may be just leave PC running)
2. Open Atom
3. Go to different workspace (At this moment **Atom window should be focused**!)
4. Wait about 3-4 secs
5. Return to workspace with Atom and see it's freezed
### Versions

atom 1.6.0-beta6 
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.5.0

Ubuntu 15.10 (amd64)
Compiz 0.8.12 on Intel HD 4600 graphics

Any suggestions about how to debug? I don't see any messages related to the issue in any type of logs (Atom, compiz, Xorg, messages, dmesg, syslog, etc).

data.title: Network Mounted Files crashes atom, when network is gone
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?

  yes

  Yes
- [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
  I don't know
- [ ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
  No

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

[Description of the bug or feature]
Network Mounted Files crashes atom, when network is gone
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Mount fs via network
2. Open project on the network fs
3. Close the network

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Atom crashes and gives 3 options: Reload, Close, Exit

data.title: Add checkbox styling
data.body:
This adds the checkbox styles from the [settings-view](https://github.com/atom/settings-view/blob/master/styles/settings-view.less#L113-L179) to core. Some packages might wanna [use them](https://github.com/atom/settings-view/issues/740) too. Also could be used for the [About](https://github.com/atom/about/pull/12) package.

![screen shot 2016-03-03 at 10 40 20 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/13481868/5cb48416-e12c-11e5-9d6c-bf6a4f225eb0.png)
## Questions
1. **Selector**? Currently uses `.checkbox[type="checkbox"]`, which means you need to use an `<input type="checkbox" class="checkbox">` to get the styling. Alternatives:
   1. `input[type="checkbox"]`: Then the class is not needed, but it would make it harder to use a custom checkbox. One day we might wanna add a "toggle switch" that also uses `<input type="checkbox">`.
   2. `.checkbox`: Some packages might already use that name in other ways (e.g. settings-view uses it as the wrapper for a checkbox). So a little more risky.
2. **Color**? Currently uses `@background-color-success`. Which is green in most themes. Alternative:
   1. Use `@background-color-info` which is blue in most themes. Would follow OS X default convention, but feel a bit uncanny if you have it set to OS X's grey theme.
## Todo
- [x] Add checkbox styles
- [x] Add `indeterminate` state
## Todo after merge
- Use in `settings-view`
- Use in `about`

data.title: Normalize The Environment And Allow Atom Windows To Have Different Environments
data.body: ### Prerequisites - [x] ~~Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?~~ - [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)? - [x] ~~Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?~~ - [x] ~~Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?~~ - [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? - [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? ### Description There are some issues with the way the user's environment is made available within Atom: - On OS X, if a user launches `Atom.app` from `Finder`, `Spotlight`, `Dock`, `open`, or another `launchd` launched process, the user's environment is anaemic and potentially varies from the user's intended environment - If a user launches `atom` from the command line multiple times, any changes in the environment for attempts `2...n` are not reflected in Atom's environment I am conflating these two issues because I propose they should be solved by adding a ~~project-level API to `atom.project` (e.g. `atom.project.getEnv()` or `atom.project.env`)~~ functionality to Atom that: - Is aware of the OS X "anaemic environment" issue and is capable of patching the environment for the implicit project that exists on first launch of Atom, if Atom was indeed launched from `Finder`, `Dock`, `Spotlight`, `open`, et a - Allows projects to have a varying environment, so that multiple invocations of `atom` from the command line can result in some change in the environment, if changes were made ~~Note that this specifically does _not_ endorse changing `process.env` nor does it seek to patch it. The actual environment for the running Atom process should be preserved, unpatched as it is still a valid environment for the original process. This also allows existing functionality to work as it always has, while providing a mechanism for package authors to opt-in to the new project-level API.~~ ### Open Questions - Is `atom.project` the right place for this? - ~~What "marker" can be used to determine - on OS X - that the environment should be patched (see https://github.com/atom-community/environment/blob/3ccde732f213452e9b897482e1a3fba1f7a4a3e2/lib/environment.js#L113-L120 for prior art)~~ We are going to use the presence of ~~`TERM`~~ `PWD` as a marker on OSX that the environment does not need to be patched - ~~Should `atom.project.getEnv()` return a promise to permit the patching, or should any patching be done synchronously (e.g. `atom.project.env`)?~~ process.env will be patched directly. - ~~Should there be lifecycle events that are associated with changes in a project's environment (e.g. `onWillChangeEnv`, `onDidChangeEnv`, etc.)?~~ No. - I'm certain there are a bunch of issues that this proposal would solve; I'd love help from @50Wliu and @lee-dohm to find them all ### Prior Art - https;//atom.io/packages/environment - https://www.npmjs.com/package/consistent-env ## The Anaemic OS X Environment Issue ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Use OS X 2. Launch Atom from `Finder`, `Spotlight`, `Dock`, `open` 3. Open the Atom console, and type `process.env` 4. Observe the environment is anaemic 5. Quit Atom 6. Launch Atom from the terminal (`atom .`) 7. Open the Atom console, and type `process.env` 8. Observe the environment is as you would expect **Expected behavior:** The environment is the same, regardless of how Atom is launched on OS X. **Actual behavior:** The environment is different, depending on how Atom is launched. ### Versions All, <= 1.7.x. ## The Multiple-Launch Issue ### Steps to Reproduce - Atom does not update its environment when a project is opened twice 1. Use any operating system 2. Launch a terminal 3. Make a directory (e.g. `directory-1`), and change your working directory to it 4. Set an environment variable called `SOMEVAR` to `true` (e.g. `export SOMEVAR=true` on OS X / Linux; `SET SOMEVAR=true` on Windows) 5. Launch `atom` from the terminal (e.g. `atom .`) 6. Observe a new Window launches, with a new project in the tree view, for the `directory-1` directory 7. Open the Atom console, and type `process.env` 8. Observe the environment has the `SOMEVAR` key set with a value of `true` 9. Go back to the terminal, and set the SOMEVAR environment variable to `false` (e.g. `export SOMEVAR=true` on OS X / Linux; `SET SOMEVAR=true` on Windows) 10. Launch Atom from the terminal (`atom .`) 11. Observe a new process launches temporarily, but then exits, and the original atom window focuses, with the `directory-1` project open 12. Open the Atom console, and type `process.env` 13. Observe the environment has the `SOMEVAR` key set with a value of `true` (although one would expect it to have a value of `false` now) - Atom does not allow different environments for different projects / windows 1. (Continued from above) 2. Change your working directory to the parent folder of `directory-1` 3. Make a directory (e.g. `directory-2`) and change your working directory to it 4. Set an environment variable called `SOMEOTHERVAR` to `true` (e.g. `export SOMEOTHERVAR=true` on OS X / Linux; `SET SOMEOTHERVAR=true` on Windows) 5. Launch `atom` from the terminal (e.g. `atom .`) 6. Observe a new Window launches, with a new project in the tree view, for the `directory-2` directory 7. Observe that the existing Window for `directory-1` is still open 8. Open the Atom console, and type `process.env` 9. Observe the environment has the `SOMEVAR` key still set to a value of `true` 10. Observe the environment has the `SOMEOTHERVAR` key undefined **Expected behavior:** There is some way for a package author to get access to the state of the environment as it existed when `atom` was last invoked to launch a Window. **Actual behavior:** Any changes in the environment for `atom` invocation `2...n` are not available to the package author. ### Versions All, <= 1.7.x. /cc @lee-dohm
